item.title: Migrants’ Lives in Ruin as Camp Is Razed in Rome
item.description: About 100 people had made homes in the camp, but the government sent in bulldozers on Monday, after new arrivals swelled the population.
item.dc:creator: ELISABETTA POVOLEDO
item.media:description: The Ponte Mammolo camp in Rome was destroyed on Monday. New migrants had swarmed to the camp, which had about 100 long-term residents.

item.title: Reporter's Notebook: Hezbollah Deploys Weapon, a Press Tour, on the Syrian Front
item.description: Hezbollah took journalists on a battlefield tour in Syria, seeking to counter the impression that its campaign is going badly after losses for its ally, Syria’s government.
item.dc:creator: ANNE BARNARD
item.media:credit: Bryan Denton for The New York Times
item.media:description: Hezbollah fighters staged a mock patrol in the Qalamoun region in Syria for journalists on a tour.

item.title: China Making Some Missiles More Powerful
item.description: The move is particularly notable because the technology of miniaturizing warheads and putting three or more atop a single missile has been in Chinese hands for decades.
item.dc:creator: DAVID E. SANGER and WILLIAM J. BROAD

item.title: Village of Bedouins Faces Eviction as Israel Envisions a Village of Jews
item.description: Some 70 Bedouin families are likely to be evicted soon from their homes in Umm al-Hiran, the village in the Negev Desert where they have been living since the 1950s.
item.category: Adalah, The Legal Center for Arab Minority Rights in Israel
item.dc:creator: DIAA HADID
item.media:description: Umm al-Hiran, in the Negev Desert, near Israel’s de facto border with the West Bank, is home to about 1,000 Bedouins who have lived there since the 1950s.

item.title: A Russian Smartphone Has to Overcome Rivals and Jokes About Origin
item.description: Few people looking to buy a state-of-the-art smartphone would even think about a Russian model, but the makers of the YotaPhone aspire to change that.
item.dc:creator: NEIL MacFARQUHAR
item.media:credit: James Hill for The New York Times
item.media:description: The YotaPhone 2 was presented to the media in Moscow last month. Young technology buffs in Russia gave it mixed reviews.

item.title: China Stands by Its Claims Over South China Sea Reefs
item.description: Top diplomat, meeting with Secretary of State John Kerry, says its focus on island-building in the South China Sea is unshaken by rising tensions.
item.dc:creator: ANDREW JACOBS
item.media:description: Secretary of State John Kerry met with the Chinese foreign minister, Wang Yi, in Beijing on Saturday.

item.title: Egyptian Court Sentences Ousted President Morsi to Death
item.description: Mr. Morsi was sentenced to death over his part in a mass prison break that took place during the 2011 uprising that toppled Hosni Mubarak.
item.dc:creator: JARED MALSIN
item.media:description: Mohamed Morsi, the deposed Egyptian president, appeared inside a cage in the Cairo courtroom where he was sentenced to death on Saturday.

item.title: ISIS Official Killed in U.S. Raid in Syria, Pentagon Says
item.description: Mr. Sayyaf, who was involved in the Islamic State’s military operations and helped managed oil and gas sales, was killed during a raid in Syria, the Pentagon said.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: HELENE COOPER and ERIC SCHMITT

item.title: In Vatican, Abbas Is Praised as ‘Angel of Peace’
item.description: Pope Francis praised Mahmoud Abbas, the president of the Palestinian Authority, as an “angel of peace” during a meeting at the Vatican on Saturday.
item.dc:creator: ELISABETTA POVOLEDO
item.media:description: Pope Francis exchanged gifts with Mahmoud Abbas, president of the Palestinian Authority, during their meeting at the Vatican on Saturday.

item.title: U.S. Special Forces Kill Senior ISIS Commander in Syria Raid, Defense Department Says
item.description: The leader, Abu Sayyaf, was involved in the group’s military operations and also helped manage black-market sales of oil and gas to raise money.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: THE NEW YORK TIMES

item.title: Russian Rocket Carrying Mexican Satellite Is Said to Crash in Siberia
item.description: The Proton-M rocket, which was ferrying a telecommunications satellite, crashed minutes after launch on Saturday, Russian news agencies reported.
item.dc:creator: DAVID M. HERSZENHORN

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: China Clears Police Officer in Death of Unarmed Man, but Controversy Isn’t Over
item.description: Investigators concluded that the officer was “appropriately performing his duty” when he fired. But the reports prompted a further outcry, and demands that the authorities release the complete, unedited surveillance video.
item.dc:creator: KIKI ZHAO
item.media:description: An image from a cellphone video shows Xu Chunhe, left, struggling with a police officer, Li Lebin, on May 2 at a train station in Qing'an, Heilongjiang Province.

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Q. and A.: Nicholas R. Lardy on Markets and the State in China
item.description: The economist argues that China’s economic boom has been fueled by private enterprise and policies that have allowed the market to play a greater role.
item.dc:creator: DAVID BARBOZA
item.media:description: A worker cutting steel bars at a plant in Ganyu, Jiangsu Province.

item.title: 8 Bodies Found in Wreckage of Marine Helicopter, Nepal Army Says
item.description: Six Marines and two Nepali soldiers were aboard the UH-1 Huey that crashed Tuesday while assisting in earthquake relief efforts.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.dc:creator: BHADRA SHARMA and NIDA NAJAR

item.title: Yemen: Aid Coordinator Asks Saudis to Simplify Restrictions
item.description: The United Nations said Friday that the relief effort in Yemen was encumbered by Saudi Arabia’s stringent import inspections.
item.dc:creator: RICK GLADSTONE
item.media:credit: Abdel Rahman Abdallah/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: A Yemeni man carried a child who had been wounded Friday in an exchange of gunfire between tribal fighters supporting the exiled president, Abdu Rabbu Mansour Hadi, and Houthi rebels. The United Nations said Friday that the effort to bring emergency aid into the country during a five-day humanitarian pause in the Saudi-led bombing of Houthi rebels and their allies was being encumbered by Saudi Arabia’s import inspections. The process “needs to be simplified,” one official said.

item.title: Latin American Allies Resist U.S. Strategy in Drug Fight
item.description: Across the Americas, governments are increasingly challenging traditional U.S.-led strategies like prohibition and the eradication of crops.
item.dc:creator: WILLIAM NEUMAN and SIMON ROMERO

item.title: World Briefing: Germany: Hackers Attack Computers in the Lower House of Parliament
item.description: Hackers have launched an attack on the computer system of the Bundestag, the lower house of the German Parliament, a parliamentary spokesman said Friday.
item.dc:creator: ALISON SMALE

item.title: World Briefing | Africa: Nigeria: Militants Retake Border Town
item.description: Fighters with the extremist group Boko Haram took back control of the border town of Marte in northeastern Nigeria on Friday.
item.dc:creator: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: World Briefing | Europe: Poland: Reparations Deadline to Be Met for 2 Terrorism Suspects Held by C.I.A.
item.description: Poland will meet a Saturday deadline set by a European court to pay a total of $260,000 in reparations to two suspected terrorists who were interrogated in a secret C.I.A. prison in Poland.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.dc:creator: JOANNA BERENDT

item.title: World Briefing: Canada: Pledge Sent to U.N. to Reduce Greenhouse Gas Emissions by 2030
item.description: Prime Minister Stephen Harper’s government said Friday that Canada would reduce greenhouse gas emissions by 30 percent below 2005 levels by 2030.
item.category: United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change
item.dc:creator: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS
